_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Employee Awareness Training.  SPCC and SWP3 site inspections.  PM.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility Description

The POET Biorefining-Emmetsburg facility is located on the southeast side of Emmetsburg, Iowa, approximately 1 mile south of Iowa Highway 18 and on the south side of 380th Street in Palo Alto county.  POET Biorefining-Emmetsburg's main product is denatured ethanol for use as motor vehicle fuel.  The facility also produces vegetable (corn) oil and dried distillers grain.  Ethanol production at the facility was initiated in March 2005. At POET Biorefining-Emmetsburg corn meal is mixed with water and a digestive enzyme to produce liquified starch, that is further converted to fermentable sugars. Yeast is added to effect fermentation of the sugars to ethanol.  The fermented mash (beer) contains about 10% alcohol and is distilled, then passed through a dehydration system, to produce 200-proof anhydrous ethanol. After final dehydration, the ethanol is collected in two 2,000,000-gallon storage tanks.  During product load-out a denaturant (natural gas condensate, NGC) is added to make the ethanol unfit for human consumption, as per federal and state requirements. NGC is blended in-line with the ethanol and transferred to vehicles for transport off-site. The denatured ethanol motor fuel may be shipped from the facility in tank trucks or rail cars.



Chemicals Regulated Under EPA's Chemical Accident Prevention Program

The NGC denaturant is the only CAPP/RMP regulated chemical which exceeds the CAPP quantity thresholds for applicability of the regulation. The CAPP/RMP regulated process consists of one NGC denaturant storage tank and the associated transfer/blending equipment and piping. The denaturant is added to the ethanol to a concentration of 2% to 5%. The greatest CAPP regulated quantity of denaturant in a tank, vessel or piping system is the quantity in the denaturant storage tank, located in the center containment area of the tank farm.  Line 1.17(c)of this submission is the total quantity of that tank (T805).  As recommended by U.S. EPA's RMP In

formation Office on June 10,  2013, Line 4.4 of the Worst Case Scenario submission is taken as QR (Eq. D-1; Risk Management Program Guidance for Off Site Consequence Analysis, EPA 550-B-99-009, March, 2009.), i.e., pounds released per minute and multiplied times ten minutes to reflect the quantity that is estimated to evaporate and participate in an un-contained vapor cloud explosion.   Similarly, line 5.4 of the Alternative Case Scenario submission is taken as QR for one minute to reflect the quantity that is estimated to evaporate and participate in an un-contained vapor cloud fire.  Details of the calculation methodology are in Appendix D of the POET Biorefining-Emmetsburg Desktop Risk Management Plan.     



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy

POET Biorefining-Emmetsburg is committed to the protection of it employees, the surrounding community and the environment from industrial materials used in the ethanol fuel production process. The company has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) as per 29 CFR 1910.38(a).  In the event of a chemical emergency, POET Biorefining-Emmetsburg's Emergency Coordinator will direct internal response activities to the extent they are within the qualifications and capabilities of company personnel, taking reasonable

precautions to prevent or minimize the extent of release or the co-mingling of materials. There is no facility emergency response team. Employees within their designated work areas will respond to small releases, if such response does not pose a danger to their health or safety. In the event of a larger release, it is the policy of POET Biorefining-Emmetsburg to notify the Emmetsburg Fire Department, evacuate or shelter-in-place all employees at the facility, and provide technical and logistics support to the Fire Department Incident Commander.



Accidental Release Prevention Program, and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

POET Biorefining-Emmetsburg is committed to protection of the enviro

nment through the combined use of inspection, maintenance, passive mitigation, employee training and response preparation.  Computer based maintenance software is utilized to implement automatic scheduling and work order generation for covered process  preventative maintenance inspections and tests.  Public access to the facility from the highway is restricted by a gate. Much of the property is fenced, limiting vehicle access. The plant is fully lighted. Personnel are typically on-site 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. There is a multi-camera video surveillance system installed at the property, and a general computer based alarm system. The alarm system includes monitoring of the storage tank(s) and denaturant blending system (level control and overfill monitors). The alarm system is monitored in the control room for abnormal conditions, which trigger visual control panel alarm lights and audible alarms. The covered process  storage tanks have secondary containment and are included in the facility Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasure (SPCC) Plan.



Five-Year Accident History

The facility has an excellent record with regard to minimizing recordable and reportable accidents. There have been no RMP-defined reportable accidents since startup of the facility which require inclusion in the five-year accident history required by Subpart B of the CAPP/RMP regulation.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

There are no current design projects or equipment procurements planned in this category at the time of this submission; however, POET Biorefining-Emmetsburg's management and operations team is committed to an on-going system of production process review, evaluation of improvements in available technology (including safety features), safety procedure observation, analysis of previous plant incidents (including plant near misses and as-applicable review of sister plant events), and Prevention Program compliance audits, to identify opportunities to improve plant safety.
